review.title: Dengue disease prediction using weka data mining tool
review.abstract: Dengue is a life threatening disease prevalent in several developed as well as developing countries like India.In this paper we discuss various algorithm approaches of data mining that have been utilized for dengue disease prediction. Data mining is a well known technique used by health organizations for classification of diseases such as dengue, diabetes and cancer in bioinformatics research. In the proposed approach we have used WEKA with 10 cross validation to evaluate data and compare results. Weka has an extensive collection of different machine learning and data mining algorithms. In this paper we have firstly classified the dengue data set and then compared the different data mining techniques in weka through Explorer, knowledge flow and Experimenter interfaces. Furthermore in order to validate our approach we have used a dengue dataset with 108 instances but weka used 99 rows and 18 attributes to determine the prediction of disease and their accuracy using classifications of different algorithms to find out the best performance. The main objective of this paper is to classify data and assist the users in extracting useful information from data and easily identify a suitable algorithm for accurate predictive model from it. From the findings of this paper it can be concluded that Na\"ive Bayes and J48 are the best performance algorithms for classified accuracy because they achieved maximum accuracy= 100% with 99 correctly classified instances, maximum ROC = 1, had least mean absolute error and it took minimum time for building this model through Explorer and Knowledge flow results

metadata.title: DENGUE DISEASE PREDICTION USING WEKA DATA MINING TOOL

sections.text: 1DENGUE DISEASE PREDICTION USING WEKA DATA MINING TOOLKASHISH ARA SHAKIL, SHADMA ANIS AND MANSAF ALAMDepartment of Computer Science, Jamia Millia IslamiaNew Delhi, Indiashakilkashish @ yahoo.co.in, shadamanis @ gmail.com and malam2 @ jmi.ac.inDengue is a life-threatening disease prevalent in several developed as well as developing countries such as India. It is a viral disease caused by the breeding of Aedes Mosquito. Data sets available for dengue describe information about patients suffering from dengue and without dengue disease along with their symptoms such as: fever temperature, WBC, Platelets, Severe Headache, Vomiting, Metallic Taste, Joint Pain, Appetite, Diarrhea, Hematocrit, Hematoglobin, and days such as many in different cities.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Correctly Classified Accuracy
sections.text: It indicates the percentage of accuracy of the test that is correctly classified.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Incorrectly Classified Accuracy
sections.text: It shows the accuracy of the test, which is incorrectly classified.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Mean Absolute Error
sections.text: It shows the number of errors needed to analyze the accuracy of the algorithm classification.3.1.4 TimeIt shows how much time it takes to build a model to predict disease.

sections.heading: 3.1.5. ROC Area
sections.text: Receiver Operating Characteric19 is a test guide for classifying accuracy of diagnostic tests based on: excellent (0.90-1), good (0.80-0.90), fair (0.60-0.70), bad (0.60-0.70), failed (0.50-0.60).

sections.heading: 4. Datasets Used
sections.text: Data set is a collection of data or individual statistical data in which each attribute of the data is variable and each instance has its own description. To predict dengue disease, we used dengue sets to predict and classify algorithms to compare their accuracy using Wekas three interfaces: Explorer, Experiment, and Knowledge Flow.Figure 2 shows a description of the dengue set. The data set we used contains 18 attributes and 108 cases for the classification and accuracy of dengue diseases. We have used various algorithms that use WEKA data-mining tools for our analysis.14Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis, and Mansaf Alam, Table 2. Describes the attributes of the data set shown in Figure 2. The file format of the data sets used is Comma Separated Value CSV. Each attribute shows the number of days of pain, number of days of errors, and number of dengue.

sections.heading: 5. Data Mining Techniques
sections.text: The data mining method has been used by us to predict dengue. Predictions have been made by us using the data mining tool from weka for classification and accuracy by applying different algorithms. Interfaces of weka used in this paper are the following:

sections.heading: 5.1. Explorer Interface
sections.text: The user can then load the data file in CSV (Comma Separated Value) format and then analyze the result of classification accuracy by selecting the following algorithms using 10 cross-validations: Naive Bayes, J48, SMO, REP Tree and Random Tree. Figure 3 shows the Explorer interface when Dengue Disease Prediction Using Weka Data Mining Tool 9using Dengue Dataset is opened using a CSV file along with its graphical view.12, 15

sections.heading: 5.1.1. Naïve Bayes
sections.text: Naïve Bayes is one of the algorithms that works as a probabilistic classifier of all the attributes contained in the data sample and then classifies data problems. By executing the algorithms with Naïve Bayes, we analyze the classifier output with as many statistical results, using 10 cross-validations to make a prediction for each instance of the dataset. 16 After executing these algorithms, we achieved a classification accuracy of 100% for 99 correctly classified instances, error rates achieved, i.e. the mean absolute error is 0.0011, the time for modeling is 0 seconds and the ROC range is 1. These results are obtained after these algorithms have been executed. Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis and Mansaf Alam, 10The accuracy achieved by evaluating the NaïveBayes algorithm is given in Table 3 on the basis of time, accuracy, error and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.1.2. J48 Tree
sections.text: J48 Tree was used in this essay to determine the target value based on various attributes of the dataset, to predict the machine learning model and to classify its accuracy. We also used J48 Tree on our dengue disease dataset. After executing this algorithm, we analyzed the results obtained from the classifier. The output provided several statistics based on 10 cross-validations to make a prediction for each instance of the dataset. Figure 5 shows the classification accuracy achieved by this algorithm, i.e. 100% is the correctly classified accuracy for a group of 99 instances, the absolute error obtained is 0, the time taken to build this model is 0 seconds, and the ROC range is 0.98.

sections.heading: 5.1.3. SMO
sections.text: SMO is one of the methods of classification. In this paper, we used this algorithm to divide the data based on the dataset. With this algorithm, we analyzed the classification output with various statistics based on the output, using 10 cross-validations to make a prediction for each instance of the dataset. Figure 6 shows the classification accuracy of 100%, the error rate, which means that an absolute error has been made, is 0 seconds, and the ROC range is 0.875, which is achieved after executing these algorithms. Evaluation of the accuracy of the J48 algorithm is given in Table 5 based on time, accuracy, error and ROC.Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis and Mansaf Alam, 12.

sections.heading: 5.1.4. REP Tree
sections.text: REP tree was used in this essay to make a decision and reduce errors by sorted values of the numerical attribute, dividing the instances into pieces to classify the accuracy. When executing the algorithm, we analyze the classification output with statistical results, using 10 cross validations to make a prediction for each instance of the data set. Figure 7 shows that the classification accuracy is achieved, that 74.7475% for 74 instances are correctly classified, 25.2525% incorrectly classified accuracy for 25 instances, error rates, meaning that the absolute error is 0.3655, the time it takes to create the model is 0.02 seconds, and the ROC range is 0.544 these are correctly classified in Output.Dengue Disease Prediction Using Weka Data Mining Tool 13Figure 7 analyzes the evaluation of the REP tree algorithm accuracy, and the output is worked out in Table 6 based on time, ROC, further on accuracy and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.1.5. Random Tree
sections.text: When executing the algorithm, we analyze the classification output with statistical results by using 10 cross-validations to make a prediction for each dataset. Figure 8 gives a classification accuracy of 87.8788%, which is correctly classified for 87 instances, 12.1212% incorrectly classified accuracy for 12 instances, error rates meaning that the absolute error is 0.1853, the time required to create this model is 0 seconds, and the ROC range is 0.876. Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis, and Mansaf Alam, 14 scoring results obtained by using random tree algorithms are given in Table 7 based on time, accuracy, error, and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.2. Experimenter Interface
sections.text: Experimental Interface was used in this paper to analyze data by experimenting with algorithms such as Naïve Bayes, J48, REP Tree, and Random Tree to classify the data by traction and testing.17 In Figure 9, we perform four different algorithms on dengue datasets and analyze algorithms for accuracy.Dengue Disease Prediction Using Weka Data Mining Tool 15

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Naïve Bayes
sections.text: It is one of the fastest algorithms works on the probability of all the attributes that are contained in the data sample individually, and then classifies them accurately.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. J48 Tree
sections.text: We used the J48 tree to determine the target value based on various attributes of the dataset to predict the accuracy of the algorithms.

sections.heading: 5.2.3. REP Tree
sections.text: We used the Weka classification tree algorithm to analyze the accuracy applied to dengue datasets.

sections.heading: 5.2.4. Random Tree
sections.text: Figure 10 analyzes experiment tests of all four algorithms, each algorithm is run ten times and the accuracy is shown. "v" stands for the best precision forecast and "*" for the worse precision forecast. This means that it predicts the best and the worst accuracy of hits among the four algorithms listed below: Naïve Bayes J48 Tree REP Tree Random TreeScoring Accuracy of Naïve Bayes, J48, REP Tree and Random Tree is given in Table 8Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis and Mansaf Alam, 16.

sections.heading: 5.3. Knowledge Flow Interface
sections.text: Knowledge Flow is an alternative to Explorer.18The user interprets the data by linking them together to form a knowledge flow by selecting the weka component from a toolbar, as shown in Figure 11.For our experiments, we connected CSV loader, class identifier, cross validation, and then an algorithm such as SMO, REP tree, etc. followed by the Classifier Performance Evaluator, and finally we look at the results using a text view.Dengue Disease Prediction Using Weka Data Mining Tool 17

sections.heading: 5.3.1. Naïve Bayes
sections.text: Naïve Bayes is the algorithm that works with the probability of all the attributes contained in the data sample and classifies data problems. We also used this algorithm in the experiment interface. In Figure 12, a 100% correctly classified accuracy is achieved for 99 instances, the error rate, which is an average absolute error, is 0.0011, the time required to create the model is 0 seconds and the ROC range is 1, these are output. Figure 12 analyzes the evaluation of the accuracy of the naive Bayes algorithm specified in Table 9 based on time, accuracy, error and ROC: Table9. Naïve Bayes algorithm accuracy algorithm TimeTaken toBuildModel (seconds) CorrectlyClassifiedInstances% AccuracyInstances% AccuracyMeanAbsoluteErROCrorBayAreveAreesNaïes100% (0) AccuracyArees100% (0)

sections.heading: 5.3.2. J48 Tree
sections.text: J48 Tree decides the target value based on various attributes of the dataset to predict the machine learning model and classify its accuracy based on dengue data.Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis and Mansaf Alam, 18Figure 13 shows that 100% of the accuracy detected from 99 cases is correctly classified, error rates meaning that the absolute error is 0, the time taken to build the model is 0 seconds and the ROC range is 1. A detailed analysis of the evaluation using the J48 algorithm is given in Table 10 on the basis of time, accuracy, error and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.3.3. SMO
sections.text: The SMO algorithm was also used by us in the Knowledge Flow Classification Interface. It divides the data based on the data set and then analyzes the results. Figure 14 shows that the classification accuracy achieved correctly classifies 100% of the 99 cases, the error rate, which is an absolute error, is 0, the time for modeling is 0 seconds and the ROC range is 0.875. The accuracy of the SMO algorithm is evaluated on the basis of Table 11 based on time, accuracy, error and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.3.4. REP Tree
sections.text: REP tree has been used in this essay to create a decision tree, thereby reducing error by sorting numerical attribute values and splitting instances into individual parts to classify accuracy. Figure 15 shows that the classification accuracy achieved is 74.7475% correctly classified accuracy, 25.2525% is incorrectly classified accuracy, error rates representing an absolute error are 0.3655, the time required for modeling is 0.02, and the ROC area is 0.544.Kashish Ara Shakil, Shadma Anis, and Mansaf Alam, 20Table 12shows the analysis of the evaluation of REP algorithm accuracy based on time, accuracy, error, and ROC.

sections.heading: 5.3.5. Random Tree
sections.text: Random Tree randomly selects attributes on each node to enable estimation of class accuracy. Figure 16 shows that the classification accuracy achieved is 87.8788% correctly classified accuracy, 12.1212% incorrectly classified accuracy, error rates representing an absolute error are 0.1853, the time it takes to build the model is 0 seconds and the ROC range is 0.876, which are output.Dengue Disease Prediction Using Weka Data Mining Tool 21Figure 16 analyzes the evaluation of J48 algorithm accuracy and is further presented in Table 13 by time, accuracy, error and ROC.

sections.heading: 6. Results and Discussion
sections.text: Explorer, experimenter and knowledge flow are the data mining techniques that were used by us with various algorithms Naïve Bayes, J48, SMO, RANDOM tree and REP tree. Through these techniques we trained the results based on the time taken to build model, correctly classified instances, errors and ROC area. Algorithm scoring accuracy is classified in Table 14.Naïve Bayes and J48 100% correct instances accuracy with minimal Naïve Bayes Mean Absolute Error J48 = 0, with maximum Naïve Bayes ROC = 1 and J48ROC Area = 0.958 and time taken to build model = 0 seconds. So from Explorer interface data mining technique we can deduce that Naïve Bayes and J48 units have maximum accuracy, least error Bayes ROC = 1 and J48ROC Area = 0.958 and time taken to build model.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: The main objective of this paper is to predict dengue disease using WEKA Data Mining Tool. It has four interfaces. From these four, we have used three interfaces: Explorer, Experiment and Knowledge Flow. Each interface has its own classification algorithms. We have used five algorithms obtained after executing these algorithms in the output window, J48, REP Tree and Random Tree for our experiments. Then, these algorithms were implemented using WEKA Data Mining technique to analyze the algorithms. After executing these algorithms, the results were compared on the basis of accuracy.

metadata.abstractText: Dengue is a life threatening disease prevalent in several developed as well as developing countries like India. This is a virus born disease caused by breeding of Aedes mosquito. Datasets that are available for dengue describe information about the patients suffering with dengue disease and without dengue disease along with their symptoms like: Fever Temperature, WBC, Platelets, Severe Headache, Vomiting, Metallic Taste, Joint Pain, Appetite, Diarrhea, Hematocrit, Hemoglobin, and how many days suffer in different city. In this paper we discuss various algorithm approaches of data mining that have been utilized for dengue disease prediction. Data mining is a well known technique used by health organizations for classification of diseases such as dengue, diabetes and cancer in bioinformatics research. In the proposed approach we have used WEKA with 10 cross validation to evaluate data and compare results. Weka has an extensive collection of different machine learning and data mining algorithms. In this paper we have firstly classified the dengue data set and then compared the different data mining techniques in weka through Explorer, knowledge flow and Experimenter interfaces. Furthermore in order to validate our approach we have used a dengue dataset with 108 instances but weka used 99 rows and 18 attributes to determine the prediction of disease and their accuracy using classifications of different algorithms to find out the best performance. The main objective of this paper is to classify data and assist the users in extracting useful information from data and easily identify a suitable algorithm for accurate predictive model from it. From the findings of this paper it can be concluded that Naïve Bayes and J48 are the best performance algorithms for classified accuracy because they achieved maximum accuracy= 100% with 99 correctly classified instances, maximum ROC = 1 , had least mean absolute error and it took minimum time for building this model through Explorer and Knowledge flow results.
